newsitem.title: FRANCE: Western advertisers try to reach Asia's consumer.
newsitem.headline: Western advertisers try to reach Asia's consumer.

text.p: Booming economies and expanding television markets in Asia are fuelling double-digit growth in advertising, with key markets such as China offering vast growth opportunities, industry experts said.

Advertising executives told Reuters Asia's increasing importance was driven home when a 350-strong delegation arrived from China to attend this year's International Advertising Festival in the French resort town of Cannes.
The Chinese delegation is one of the biggest from any country at Cannes, where some 6,000 delegates arrived from 70 countries earlier this week to attend the six-day festival.

Tomaz Mok, the executive creative director for McCann-Erickson Guangming Ltd advertising agency in China, described how advertising was basically not allowed for decades after the communists came to power.
In the old days, when the Peoples Republic of China was established its 1949, advertising was not very popular, he told Reuters this week at Cannes.
There was no free enterprise, no market economy, no brand names, he said.
But that's all changing with rapid economic growth and economic liberalisation in China.
Mok said China now had hundreds of television channels, including some national networks.
Advertising expenditure in China shot up to $1.1 billion in 1996, a 34-percent increase over 1995, and that kind of growth is expected to continue, Mok said.
"Theres a great opportunity for multinationals to communicate about their products," he said.
Across Asia, Western-based multinationals such as Unilever Plc and Procter & Gamble have driven much of the region's growth in advertising.
But executives at Cannes said Asian companies now played an equally important role in the growth of marketing services.
Advertising executives in Cannes said many Asian countries were also finding their own voice in advertising rather than just adopting Western-style ads.
In China, Procter & Gamble is the largest advertiser, followed by Jian Li Baa, a Chinese soft-drinks company, and Qin Chi, a local wine company.

Delegates at Cannes told Reuters they saw huge potential for introducing new products to a population whose disposable income was growing fast, but which had been isolated from internationally-branded consumer products.

Geoff Thompson, worldwide creative director for Foote Cone & Belding, the U.S.-based ad agency owned by True North Communications Inc, described a recent research his agency did by visiting homes in rural parts of China.
"People have a SONY TV and a stereo, but they dont know what toothpaste is ... But they will," he said.

Western-based multinationals such as Nestle SA, Johnson & Johnson and Coca-Cola have entered China, bringing a certain Western advertising influence, but have also found they had to adapt their commercial message to Chinese tastes.
"In general, informative advertising is very popular" in China, said Mok, whose agency is linked to U.S.-based McCann-Erickson, which is owned by Interpublic Group of Companies Inc.
"The features of a particular product make a difference, rather than the brand name," he said.
Executives at Cannes said so-called lifestyle ads or those using Western-style humour to promote products were not very successful in China.
To succeed, local and foreign ad agencies must know how to cope with government restrictions in China.
The government in Beijing strictly regulates advertising, banning television advertising of tobacco and of alcoholic spirits.
There are strict regulations on how medical products can be portrayed in ads. And all forms of "comparative advertising", where the advertiser's product is compared to competitors', is also banned.
"You cant say Coke tastes better than Pepsi," Mok said. "You cant even say, 'glasses are passe. Wear contact lenses instead.'"
In more developed advertising markets in Asia, Western-based companies are learning they can only reach Asian consumers if they truly speak their language.
Executives at Cannes said Western-style advertising used to be considered the best by many consumers in countries like Singapore, India and Malaysia.
But that's changing. "Up until about five years ago
advertising in Malaysia had been total Europhile, Yasmin Ahmad, executive creative director for Leo Burnett in Malaysia, told Reuters.
"But five to seven years ago people realised consumers (in Malaysia) didn't care about advertising trends in Europe and America, she said.
Japan, the world's second largest advertising market after the United States, and Thailand have their own distinctive advertising styles which don't borrow much from the West.
Western-style advertising still works pretty well in Singapore, Ahmad said.

But in Malaysia, where the advertising industry is worth an annual $1.0 billion and is growing by 18 percent a year, some consumers relate to Western-style marketing, while others want a more Malaysian-style commercial message.
